name: Ogun
description:
The First House of the Zodiac, ruled by the Ascendant, represents the acting self—how you present your personality to the world. Governed by Mars, the Roman god of war, this house embodies action, drive, and initiation. These qualities mirror the fierce and determined energy of Ogun, the Orisha of iron, war, and technology. As the spiritual counterpart to Aries, Ogun exemplifies courage, independence, and assertiveness. He is the patron of warriors in all forms—soldiers, police officers, surgeons, bodybuilders, railroad workers, welders, and anyone who shapes the world through strength and precision.

Much like the blacksmith who molds raw metal into form, the First House symbolizes the ongoing process of shaping both your inner identity and outward expression. Ogun's presence empowers this transformation, offering the fortitude to face obstacles and the energy to pursue your goals. His connection to Mars intensifies this dynamic force, aligning with moments of bold beginnings and fearless action.

To honor Ogun, rituals can be performed during Aries season or during Mars-influenced astrological events. Symbols such as iron tools and red candles serve as powerful offerings. Invoking Ogun’s energy can awaken your inner warrior, helping you take decisive steps toward your highest potential and guiding you through times of challenge and growth.

name: Oshun
description: Taurus rules the second house in astrology, known as the House of Possessions. This includes not only material wealth but also the personal traits, values, and qualities we cherish within ourselves. Governed by Venus—the Roman goddess of love and beauty—Taurus is deeply connected to themes of sensuality, stability, and abundance. Venus's Orisha counterpart is Oshun, the beloved goddess of fresh waters, fertility, sensuality, love, and prosperity. Unlike Yemoja, who rules the vast ocean, Oshun is associated with rivers and streams—symbolizing nourishment, flow, and emotional depth. Often depicted as a radiant young woman adorned in gold, she is celebrated for her compassion and healing presence, especially among the poor and sick. Oshun’s energy aligns closely with the essence of Taurus: grounded, indulgent, and attuned to beauty and pleasure. To honor Oshun, you can create rituals during Taurus season or on days influenced by Venus. Include offerings and symbols sacred to her, such as honey, gold jewelry, cinnamon, oranges, or a hand mirror. By invoking Oshun’s presence, you invite love, creativity, sensual joy, and emotional abundance into your life—reminding you to value both your inner worth and the pleasures of the physical world.

name: Ibeji
description: The third house in astrology is ruled by Gemini and associated with communication, thought processes, siblings, short journeys, and writing. Its Orisha counterpart is Ibeji, the sacred divine twins in Yoruba tradition. While they appear as two, the Ibeji are considered one Orisha—two bodies sharing one soul, representing duality, unity, and the sacred balance of life. In Yoruba culture, twins are revered as magical and destined, bound together through spiritual purpose. The Ibeji embody the dual forces of nature: light and shadow, joy and sorrow, thought and emotion. They are aligned with the qualities of Gemini—curiosity, adaptability, versatility, and youthful energy. Governed by Mercury, the planet of intellect and communication, the Ibeji invite us to embrace both playfulness and mental agility. To honor the Ibeji, you can perform rituals during Gemini season or Mercury-aligned astrological events. Symbols such as twin dolls or figurines can represent their presence. Working with the energy of the Ibeji can help you reconnect with joy, find balance between opposing forces within yourself, and stay open to the wonder and mystery of everyday life.

name: Yemaya
description: The fourth house of the Zodiac is ruled by Cancer and governs themes of home, family, roots, and emotional security. Cancer is a deeply maternal and intuitive sign, embodying protection, nurturing, and the instinct to care for others. These qualities are beautifully mirrored in Yemaya, the Orisha of the ocean and the great mother of all Orisha. Her name, a contraction of the Yoruba phrase 'Yeye omo eja,' means 'Mother whose children are like fish'—a reflection of her boundless maternal care and connection to the sea. Yemaya is the patron spirit of women, especially mothers and pregnant women, and is often honored as a source of emotional healing and protection. Governed by the Moon, Cancer’s ruling celestial body, Yemaya is closely tied to lunar rhythms and the tides, symbolizing emotional ebb and flow. To honor Yemaya’s energy, you can perform rituals during Cancer season or Moon-related astrological events. Symbols such as ocean water, seashells, fish, or crescent moons can help you connect with her. Inviting Yemaya into your spiritual practice encourages emotional healing, deep intuition, and comfort through life’s changing currents.

name: Orula
description: The fifth house of the Zodiac, ruled by Leo, governs creativity, pleasure, and the joyful expression of life through art, play, romance, and even procreation. Its ruling celestial body, the Sun, symbolizes vitality, illumination, and the divine spark of inspiration. These powerful themes align with Orula (also known as Orunmila), the Orisha of wisdom, divination, and destiny. Orula holds the sacred duty of recording each person’s fate from the moment they receive the breath of life. His energy radiates with insight, guidance, and foresight—qualities that illuminate life’s path much like the Sun itself. Though often associated with Cancer due to his intuitive wisdom, Orula’s connection to Leo comes from the solar qualities he embodies: light, clarity, and healing through divine knowledge. To honor Orula during Leo season or on Sun-related astrological events, incorporate sun symbols into your practice—such as gold or yellow candles, radiant imagery, or offerings of light. By invoking Orula’s presence, you align with the creative power of the Sun, receiving the wisdom and courage needed to move forward with purpose, confidence, and clarity.

name: Esu
description: The sixth house of the Zodiac, aligned with the sign Virgo, focuses on health, service, routine, and the ways we bring order to our daily lives. Governed by Mercury—the planet of intellect, communication, and travel—this house is about refining, analyzing, and preparing. These qualities mirror the energy of Eshu, also known as Elegua, the Orisha of crossroads, communication, and divine messages. Eshu serves as the intermediary between humans and the Orisha, standing at the spiritual threshold where all interactions with the divine must begin. Just as Virgo clears paths through analysis and service, Eshu clears the way for spiritual connection, ensuring messages are received with clarity and intention. A guardian of beginnings and endings, he is also known as a trickster who teaches through unexpected turns. To connect with Eshu’s energy, rituals may be performed during Virgo season or on Mercury-aligned astrological days. Offerings like cowrie shells, keys, or statues of Elegua are traditional symbols of his presence. Engaging with Eshu helps enhance your adaptability, decision-making, and communication, guiding you with wisdom as you navigate life’s many crossroads. Always approach him with respect and sincerity, for Eshu opens the doors to deeper insight and spiritual truth.

name: Oshun
description: Oshun is the Yoruba Orisha of fresh water, love, beauty, fertility, and diplomacy. Known for her grace, sensuality, and charm, she is deeply connected to emotional healing and the sacred feminine. As the embodiment of divine femininity and pleasure, Oshun guides those who seek harmony in relationships and inner balance. Her association with the zodiac sign Libra reflects her desire for justice, peace, and aesthetic refinement. Oshun’s presence invites emotional openness, artistic expression, and the nurturing of both self and others.

name: Oya
description: The eighth house of the Zodiac, ruled by Scorpio, governs transformation, death, rebirth, sex, and the mysteries of the unseen. This house represents the cycles of destruction and renewal that are essential to spiritual growth. Oya, the Orisha of wind, storms, and profound change, embodies the essence of this house. She is the force behind the tornadoes that uproot, the tempests that cleanse, and the winds that carry souls to the spirit realm. As a gatekeeper of death and rebirth, Oya is both feared and revered for her power to initiate deep, life-altering transformation. Aligned with Scorpio’s intensity, passion, and regenerative nature, and ruled by Pluto—the planet of power, rebirth, and the subconscious—Oya teaches us that all endings hold the seed of a new beginning. To honor Oya, rituals can be performed during Scorpio season or Pluto-related transits. Incorporate symbols like black candles, obsidian, feathers, or storm water to invoke her presence. Meditating on Oya’s energy can help you release what no longer serves you, face change with courage, and embrace the transformative journey with strength and clarity. She is the fierce wind that clears your path and the guardian who ushers you through life’s most powerful transitions.

name: Obatala
description: The ninth house of the Zodiac is the domain of higher learning, philosophy, travel, and spiritual growth. Ruled by Sagittarius and governed by Jupiter—the planet of wisdom, abundance, and expansion—this house represents our pursuit of deeper meaning and broader horizons. Obatala, the Orisha of purity, wisdom, and creation, embodies these principles. He is said to have been sent by the Supreme Being to form the Earth at the dawn of time and is credited with shaping the human body, placing the head last, thus earning the title 'owner of heads.' The head is symbolic of intellect, discernment, and higher understanding—core traits of the ninth house. As the father of all Orisha, Obatala is associated with peace, clarity, and justice. His alignment with Sagittarius reflects a quest for truth, ethical leadership, and spiritual elevation. To honor Obatala, perform rituals during Sagittarius season or during Jupiter-aligned events. Use white candles, white cloth, or offerings of coconut or rice to invite his presence. By connecting with Obatala’s energy, you open yourself to inner wisdom, personal growth, and divine guidance, allowing your spirit to expand beyond limitations and into the fullness of your purpose.

name: Babalu-Aye
description: The tenth house of the Zodiac, ruled by Capricorn and the planet Saturn, governs career, public life, social roles, and long-term goals. It reflects how we strive for recognition, status, and purpose in the broader structure of society. Saturn’s energy brings discipline, responsibility, and the karmic lessons required to achieve lasting success. In Yoruba cosmology, Saturn is associated with Babalú-Ayé, the Orisha of disease, healing, and divine retribution. Also known as Omolu or Sopona, Babalú-Ayé is both feared and revered as a powerful force capable of spreading illness and offering miraculous healing. Known as the 'Wrath of the Supreme God,' he punishes transgressions yet also brings deep purification and renewal. His alignment with Capricorn emphasizes the hard-earned wisdom that comes through trials, structure, and perseverance. To honor Babalú-Ayé, rituals can be held during Capricorn season or Saturn-aligned astrological events. Offerings may include white or brown candles, grains, or symbolic items like crutches or dogs—creatures closely associated with his lore. By working with Babalú-Ayé’s energy, you can navigate hardship with grace, strengthen your resilience, and manifest healing in both your personal and public life through devotion and disciplined growth.

name: Shango
description: Shango, the Orisha of thunder, lightning, fire, drumming, and masculine vitality, is a powerful force of action and transformation. Ruled by Uranus and the zodiac sign Aquarius, the eleventh house represents friendships, groups, and revolutionary ideals. Shango embodies the bold, innovative spirit of Aquarius through his passionate leadership and dramatic displays of power. Though once a mortal king, his miraculous deeds after death elevated him to divine status. He is the brother of Babalú-Ayé, linked to the house of public roles and legacy. Shango’s energy channels strength, celebration, and courage—ideal for those navigating change, rebellion, or communal causes. His association with Aquarius and Uranus adds a layer of radical liberation, inspiring collective movements and social evolution. Honoring Shango during the Aquarius season or Uranus transits—by lighting red candles or incorporating iron—can invoke inner strength and a deeper connection to personal power, creativity, and justice.

name: Olokun
description: Olokun, the Orisha of the ocean depths, governs the twelfth house of the Zodiac, ruled by Neptune and the sign Pisces. This mysterious realm symbolizes the subconscious, dreams, isolation, and hidden knowledge. Like the ocean floor—where Olokun is bound by seven chains—this house holds ancient secrets and unseen forces. Olokun’s energy resides in altered states of consciousness, spiritual initiation, and visionary insight. Associated with Pisces’ intuitive, empathetic qualities and Neptune’s dreamlike, spiritual power, Olokun awakens the inner genius and the soul’s deepest callings. This Orisha teaches that what is hidden may be most powerful. Honoring Olokun during Pisces season or Neptune-related events—using seashells, blue candles, or meditation—can help you access wisdom from beyond the veil and invite transformative healing through emotional and spiritual depth.

name: Aganju
description: Aganju is the Orisha of volcanoes, the wilderness, and untamed land. He represents raw strength, stamina, and unyielding will. As a force of nature, Aganju symbolizes inner fire and spiritual endurance. He is often invoked during times of transformation and challenge. Some traditions describe him as a sibling or father to Shango.

name: Aje
description: Aje is the spirit of wealth and economic prosperity, often associated with marketplaces and trade. She governs material success and the responsible management of resources. Aje is revered by entrepreneurs and those seeking financial growth. Her power reminds us that abundance must be balanced with generosity and integrity.

name: Ala
description: Ala is the Igbo goddess of the earth, morality, fertility, and the underworld. As the mother of all living things, she governs the cycle of life and death. Ala also serves as the guardian of communal laws and ethics. Her presence ensures harmony between humanity and the natural world.

name: Alegba
description: Alegba is a variant of Eleggua, the divine messenger and guardian of the crossroads. He opens and closes spiritual paths and facilitates communication between humans and the divine. Alegba is invoked for guidance, clarity, and decision-making. He teaches us to pay attention to signs and consequences at life’s intersections.

name: Aso
description: Aso symbolizes sacred cloth and the cultural memory carried through fabric. In Yoruba tradition, clothing is a form of spiritual expression and social identity. Aso is honored in ceremonies and rites where ancestral lineage is celebrated. It reminds us of the threads that bind us to heritage and purpose.

name: Egun
description: Egun refers to the collective spirit of the ancestors in Yoruba spirituality. Honored through ritual and offerings, Egun represents ancestral wisdom, protection, and continuity. They act as guides for the living and demand respect for tradition and moral conduct. Ancestral veneration is central to spiritual grounding.

name: Eji-Ogbe
description: Eji-Ogbe is the first and most powerful of the 256 Odu in the Ifá divination system. It represents light, truth, and new beginnings. This sign offers divine clarity and reinforces alignment with one’s destiny. Eji-Ogbe teaches that clarity and honesty bring lasting transformation.

name: Eleggua
description: Eleggua is the Orisha of roads, doors, and crossroads. As a divine trickster and gatekeeper, he controls fate and opportunity. He must be honored first in rituals to open pathways. Eleggua embodies both mischief and wisdom, teaching lessons through the twists and turns of life.

name: Erinle
description: Erinle is a hunter and healer Orisha, closely linked to rivers and the forest. He represents the merging of science and nature, often called upon for physical and spiritual healing. Erinle’s energy is gentle yet powerful, guiding those who work in healthcare, herbalism, and caretaking.

name: Esau
description: Esau, though more rooted in biblical tradition, can be interpreted symbolically in syncretic traditions. He represents human struggle, ego, and primal instinct. His story is a lesson in self-control, birthright, and reconciliation. Esau teaches the dangers of impulse and the value of patience.

name: Igbale
description: Igbale refers to the ancestral realm in Yoruba cosmology, where spirits reside after death. It is a sacred space of rest, reflection, and continuation. Igbale teaches the importance of remembering those who came before and maintaining spiritual cleanliness. It’s invoked in funeral rites and ancestor worship.

name: Iku
description: Iku is the spirit of death in Yoruba belief. Not seen as evil, Iku is a necessary force that marks the end of one journey and the beginning of another. Death, under Iku, is a return to the ancestral fold. This Orisha reminds us of impermanence and the cycle of rebirth.

name: Ira
description: Ira represents the wisdom and spiritual might of the elders in Yoruba society. As a symbol of matriarchal leadership and ancestral memory, Ira honors the power of women in family and governance. Her influence ensures continuity of tradition and generational knowledge.

name: Iroko
description: Iroko is the sacred spirit that inhabits the ancient Iroko tree, known for its connection to time and ancestral power. It is a guardian of wisdom and silence. Offerings are often made to Iroko to secure blessings or settle spiritual debts. Iroko represents stillness, age, and continuity.

name: Iyalode
description: Iyalode is a title and figure representing the highest-ranking woman in Yoruba society. She governs women’s affairs and serves as a voice in political and spiritual matters. Iyalode embodies female authority, honor, and balance. Her wisdom is instrumental in community decision-making.

name: Ochosi
description: Ochosi is the Orisha of the hunt, law, and justice. A master archer and tactician, he represents accuracy in action and thought. He protects the innocent and pursues righteousness. Ochosi's influence is vital for those who seek clarity, discipline, and fairness in life.

name: Oda-Iya-Mimo
description: Oda-Iya-Mimo, meaning 'Holy Mother’s Seat,' refers to the divine feminine principle in sacred spaces. She represents purity, nurturing power, and spiritual boundaries. This force is revered in rituals of consecration and divine protection. She stands as the matron of sacred wisdom and divine order.

name: Olodumare
description: Olodumare is the Supreme Creator in Yoruba cosmology, the origin of all life and existence. Beyond gender and form, Olodumare embodies the totality of divine energy. Though not worshipped directly, all Orishas act through Olodumare’s will. This force reminds us of unity, balance, and divine order.

name: Olosa
description: Olosa is the Orisha of lagoons and estuaries, representing mystery, femininity, and the unseen currents of emotion. She governs transitions between fresh and salt water. Often considered a counterpart or aspect of Oshun, Olosa reminds us of the hidden depths of feminine power and intuition.

name: Orunmila
description: Orunmila is the Orisha of wisdom, divination, and fate, guardian of the Ifá oracle. He knows the path of every soul and aids in decoding destiny. Orunmila is consulted through Babalawos and sacred rituals. He brings clarity, peace, and alignment with spiritual purpose.

name: Osain
description: Osain is the Orisha of herbs, healing, and plant magic. He is a solitary, powerful spirit who knows the secrets of all natural remedies. Osain is essential to traditional healers and herbalists. His energy teaches reverence for the natural world and the quiet force of healing.
